content.description:
Climbs the steep thin face right of

Big Brother

via a series of thin edges, sloping dishes and body tension. Run up the easy slab to topout or just traverse over to Big Brother's finish and drop off onto pads.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.location: Northeast corner and the lowest point of the boulder.

content.description:
Climbs the face around and left from

Big Brother

using slopers and edges to finish up and easy slab. Downclimb the slab until you're able to jump off.

Incorrectly called Unnamed V0 in the current Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide.
content.location: Northeast corner and the lowest point of the boulder.

content.description:
Starts from head height slopers and a quick pull into the rock to gain more slopers before it's over at about the 12 foot level. Continue up easy slab or just reverse the moves as far as possible and jump off to descend.

Rated V3 in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but it seems a bit easier than similarly rated problems nearby.
content.location: Northeast corner and the lowest point of the boulder.

content.description:
Climbs a tall slab with a low crux through a whitish patch of rock and a somewhat scary topout with the loosest holds up high.

Descend the backside and jump off above the Big Brother problem.

Climb the tall face left of

The 4th Amendment

(V0 R) passing through some obvious patina patches. Gets way off the ground and is a little spooky up high.

Descend the backside and jump off above the Big Brother problem.
